title: The Indian Gynaec Experience
snippet: Learn how to navigate your gynaec appointments.
intro:
Welcome!
This workshop is for women who want to take charge of their health while being 
better prepared for the realities of visiting a gynaecologist in India.

Many women are met with judgmental questions, unnecessary assumptions, or even 
moral policing during visits. That should never stop you from seeking care.

In this space, you’ll learn:
• Your rights as a patient
• How to prepare for a gynac visit
• Scripts to handle difficult questions
• Tools to support your health journey

Remember: your health belongs to you.

The workshop will have multiple Journaling questions — you can either answer them here or in your own diaries.

items.title: The Indian Gynaec Experience
items.content:
**Your vagina doesn’t care about your marital status — it deserves care either way. So let’s get that check up done.**
Regular visits are important for overall health: menstrual health, PCOS, infections, contraception, fertility planning, and preventive screening.
The problem is, stigma persists. Common discriminatory behaviors include:
- • Questions about marital status before giving care.
- • Refusal of contraception to unmarried women
- • Invasive or shaming questions about sexual history.
- • Body shaming
- • Insistence on calling parents/partners for approval

items.title: When the Gynaec Says: ‘No Ring, No Thing’
items.content:
*When I went for a check-up at 24, the doctor asked, ‘Why are you here if you aren’t married? You don’t need to worry about your reproductive health until then.’ I felt dismissed and embarrassed - and I avoided check-ups for 3 years after that.*
The doctor never asked if I was there for any symptoms. She didn’t check if I was sexually active. She straight away dismissed my presence because I was unmarried.

questions.question: A doctor can call your parents/Partner if you’re unmarried and seek an abortion.
Which of these is a patient right in India?
Is prescribing contraception(other than condoms) illegal for unmarried women?
Are emergency contraceptives banned in India?
Do I need my partner's consent to get an abortion?
At what age can you consent to your own treatment without a guardian?

items.title: Good news!
items.content:
You have legal rights as a patient in India, here are some!
•Right to privacy (consultation should be confidential).
•Right to informed consent (doctor must explain treatment and seek your approval).
•Right to refuse (you can say no to any test or procedure).
•Right to dignity (you cannot be shamed, denied, or humiliated).
•**Abortion Rights**: Under the MTP Act abortions are legal up to 20-24 weeks with conditions — and unmarried women are entitled to access. Only the pregnant person’s consent is required.
**Contraception Access:** Doctors cannot legally refuse contraception because of marital status.
**Consent Age:** At 18+, you can legally consent to your own medical treatment.
**Emergency Contraception** is NOT banned in india.

resources.label: Legal Rights of a Patient in India

items.title: Bad news!
items.content: Emergency contraceptive pills are not banned in India, but access may be challenging in most parts of India due to unofficial restrictions and ongoing policy debates about their regulation.

rows: Generally easier, but with pockets of misinformation

modules.title: Tackling Judgment in the Doctor’s Room

items.title: Why it matters
items.content:
Most times doctors make comments that feel judgmental — like “You shouldn’t be sexually active before marriage” or “Period pain is normal, stop fussing.” It can feel scary or even silencing, and that’s not okay. You deserve respectful care.
**What can you do:**
•**Acknowledge the discomfort (to yourself):**It’s normal to feel anxious, angry, or even ashamed in the moment. That reaction doesn’t mean you’re weak — it means the situation is unfair. We do not deserve judgement for seeking care!
